I am a <font size="4">**biomedical engineer**</font> at the [<span style="color: rgb(142,71,133)">Center for Neurodevelopmental and Imaging Research</span>](https://www.kennedykrieger.org/research/centers-labs-cores/center-for-neurodevelopmental-and-imaging-research) at Kennedy Krieger Institute and an <font size="4">**Assistant Professor**</font> in the [<span style="color: rgb(142,71,133)">Department of Neurology</span>](https://www.hopkinsmedicine.org/neurology_neurosurgery/) at Johns Hopkins University.  

How do children <font size="4">**learn**</font> to interpret sensory information <font size="4">**to produce**</font> appropriate <font size="4">**actions**?</font>

I use functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) and video-based assessments of behavior to try to understand this problem. Given the inherent challenges of scanning young populations, I also help develop analysis methods that make the most of the available data by minimizing artifacts and maximizing the reproducibility and generalizability of fMRI-derived connectivity metrics.

<font size = "4">**Team science**</font> is the <font size="4">**best science**</font>, so if you'd like to collaborate, please reach out!
